out_desc_tool: The AWMA is a computerized test battery that assesses four different aspects of WM and has been standardized for use with typically developing children aged four and above.  All of the memory tasks started at a span level of one (one item of information to remember) and moved to the next span level, increasing by one storage item per span when the child got four correct answers (administration would discontinue if the child got three trials incorrect at a particular span level). The word recall task required the children listen to and recall a series of single words in the correct order (no visual support).

The NGRT Digitial Edition provided a post-test measure of reading comprehension and is based on assessments of sentence and passage completion. Schools administered the digital testing online under exam conditions and these were automatically scored by GL Assessment and therefore blind to treatment allocation.

out_tit_tool: End of Year 6 KS2 Literacy SATs scores
out_desc_tool: In each year of the KS2 study (Years 4-6) we collected a range of information on TAs and other adults in the classes. On the basis of this information, associations with measures of pupils' progress in the same classes were calculated, the aim being to see if there was any evidence that the presence in class of TAs or other staff and adults, or any characteristics of TAs (such as training, experience), had an influence on pupils' achievements. Total sample 5755, but not given amounts for control and intervention.

Passage comprehension (standardized). The child attempted items in the passage comprehension subtest of the Woodcock Reading Mastery Tests. This subtest used a cloze procedure to assess comprehension. (Scores could range from 0 to 36.)

Data from Tables 4 and 5. Mean gains from Table 5 were added to Table 4, using the SDs from Table 5.  In the great majority of schools, the Salford Sentence Reading test (Bookbinder, 1976) and the Vernon Spelling test (Vernon, 1977) were used. The main measure for this study was change in test scores over 1 year, and in all cases the same tests were used at the beginning and at the end of the year; therefore, questions of restandardization were not considered immediately relevant.

out_tit_tool: Single Word Reading subtest from York Assessment of Reading (YARC)
out_desc_tool: All children completed the Early Word Recognition (EWR) test (a = 0.98) from the York Assessment of Reading (YARC) Early Reading battery (Hulme et al., 2009). Children reading over 25 words were given an additional set of words from the Test of Single-Word Reading, from the YARC.

A computerised assessment, the New Group Reading Test Digital (NGRT; GL Assessment, 2010) was used at all time points except t4. The test took approximately 45 min to complete and was supervised by one of the TAs in school. This is an adaptive, multiple-choice test that begins with a sentence completion task and then, depending upon the accuracy of responses, either drops down in difficulty to phonics tasks or becomes harder and assesses passage comprehension. The comprehension questions target a range of skills including inferencing and vocabulary. Given the adaptive nature of the test, pupils complete different subtests. Note: Reading Ability Scores (not standard scores) are reported, hence outcome is listed as a secondary measure.

The mean slope for the treatment group was positive and indicated that, on the average, the participants in the treatment group gained 6.01 percent accuracy every three weeks. The mean slope for the control group was negative and indicated that these participants’ scores declined by 3.34 percent accuracy every three weeks. This difference in average linear slopes was statistically significant t (24) = 4.03, p < .001.

Basic Number Screening test (BNST), TA small group versus control. The test was administered to all year 8 participants as a group in each school. The test was presented orally by the researcher following standardised instructions and lasted around 30 minutes. As the instructions are exactly the same for both parallel forms of the test this allowed for all Year 8 participants in each school to be assessed together.  Adjusted post-test scores from Table
WIAT II was used to examine handwriting and text production and word, sentence and text level at each assessment time and compared performance on raw scores across the time periods.
out_type_tool: ['Toolkit primary outcome', 'Writing and spelling primary outcome.']

out_desc_tool: Post test scores for reading comprehension-Teaching assistants group, based on the Comprehensive Test of Basic Skills (CTBS).
Early Word Reading (yielding measures of Prose Reading Accuracy and Reading Comprehension) from the YARC
The YARC Early Word Reading assessed single word reading (t1, t3, t4, t5, t6). Text reading accuracy and reading comprehension (t6) was assessed using the YARC beginner passage

Listening comprehension: Children’s listening compre- hension skills were tested by asking children to listen to two short stories adapted from the York Assessment of Reading for Comprehension (YARC, Snowling et al., 2009) and answer questions about them (t1–t3).
The Letter-Word Identification Subtest of the WJ-R measures the ability of students to identify letter names and read words.

The Word Reading subtest from the British Ability Scales II is a test of single word recognition. The stimuli range from words most commonly found in children’s reading materials to words encountered infrequently. The children were presented with a list of the stimulus items printed on a card and were encouraged to read as many of those words as they could. The test was discontinued when the child passed fewer than three items in a block of ten.

Post-test adjusted mean score from GL New Group Reading Test for students not reaching level 4 KS2. Administered by computer to measure reading comprehension and fluency using sentence completion and passage comprehension adaptive excercises.
Standardized Progressive Achievement Tests (PAT; Australian Council for Educational Research, 2001)
DIBELS-Letter Naming Fluency change in means and SDs extracted in combined for treatment groups A and A2 versus comparison group.
Post test mean score for reading ability-One on one tuition group. Word Recognition and Phonics skills test

Scores from Letter-Word Identification and Passage Comprehension were selected as a measure of participants’ English broad reading ability. Letter-Word Identification consists of a list of letters and words that students name or read aloud. Each item is coded either correct or incorrect, with 1 point for correct and 0 for incorrect, with a total possible raw score of 57.
Post test mean score for word reading- Own Voice Intensive Phonics group. British Abilities Scale II (BAS II) untimed word reading test.
This is the ES reported in the study to compare against calculated from the raw scores.
The British Ability Scales (BAS II) Word Reading Test (Elliott, Smith, & McCulloch, 1997).

The Progress Test in Mathematics assesses mathematics more generally and includes items related to shape, data handling, and algebra in addition to the number and numeracy of the intervention. For the delayed post-test (administered in October, November and December 2017), the pupils, who were then in Year 4, 5 and 6, took the age-appropriate paper and pencil versions of the test: PTM 8, 9 and 10, respectively.

Basic Number Screening Test immediately before the intervention and immediately after the intervention had been completed, from which mathematics ages were calculated. ANOVAs, with group (‘intervention group’ vs ‘matched-time group’ controls vs ‘no- intervention group’ controls) as the grouping factor, were undertaken to check whether the groups differed at the outset in ways that might have affected results.

Phonological Awareness Subtest of the Test of Preschool Early Literacy (TOPEL). The analysis did not reveal a statistically significant difference between the groups on phonological awareness, F (1, 27) = 2.043, p = . 164, d - 0.755.

PSF measures children’s ability to segment words into individual phonemes. ANCOVA was used to examine the effect of the intervention on this variable by comparing groups at post-intervention and again at maintenance one month later; pre-intervention PSF scores were entered as the covariate.

out_tit_tool: RAPT Bus Story (T Vs C) Post test scores
out_desc_tool: Renfrew Action Picture Test Bus story was used for assessing language - administered by local SLTs.
Means and SD's for gain scores on the Boder Test of Reading Spelling Patterns and The Neale Analysis of Reading. Overall gains provided

out_tit_tool: Progress in Reading Assessment (PIRA) TA only
out_desc_tool: Post test adjusted score for reading ability (phonics, literal comprehension, and reading for meaning). Progress in Reading Assessment (PIRA) test. Non-ICT group.
Pre-test (computer version) post-test (paper version) age-standardised score for reading comprehension measured by the New Group Reading Test (NGRT) - GL Assessment.
The Metropolitan Achievement Test for reading and language arts was administered by district officials to all students at the end of the second grade.

The test used was originally designed by the University of Leeds for the evaluation of the National Numeracy Project, and covers all elements of the English National Curriculum in mathematics. ES supplied by author 15May19
TOPEL Phonological Awareness subtest Table 5. Multilevel model results for unique effects models - t-values

The primary outcome for the trial was the Quantitative Reasoning Test, which focuses on number knowledge and mathematical problem solving. (Nunes et al., 2007). The measure was chosen for its relevance to the intervention programme and its psychometric properties.

The primary outcome measure used in the evaluation was the Hodder Group Reading Test (HGRT) 2A (Vincent and Crumpler, 2007). This test aims to test reading comprehension at word, sentence, and continuous text level and is suitable for use with mixed ability groups.

A post-test mean score for integrated Louisiana Educational Assessment Program (iLEAP) on English Language Arts (ELA). The grade 3 test consists of four parts: (a) Writing, (b) Using Information Resources, (c) Reading, (d) Language. The test includes NRT and CRT items. The NRT items are from the survey battery (short form) of the Iowa Tests of Basic Skills. Most of the items measure Louisiana Grade Level Expectations (GLEs). The survey battery is used to provide national norms. Reading and Language are the NRT components. NB: National test

Word reading skill data were also obtained through administration of the word reading test (WRT) from the WIAT II UK (Wechsler, 2005). WIAT-II UK WRT for cohorts C & D - t-test of difference at post-test t=1.398
This is the toolkit primary ioitcome, the sample n for this outcome is 501 and 505. See Table 10.

out_tit_tool: Basic Number Screening Test - Catch up TA group
out_desc_tool: Comparison of 'business as usual' control group and and 'Catch Up' group.
Pupils’ literacy skills were estimated using the New Group Reading Test (Test 3a and 3b).

The accuracy and comprehension subtests of the Neale Analysis of Reading Ability, Revised (Neale, 1988) were used to assess word recognition accuracy in text and reading comprehension ability. The children were asked to read aloud a series of short passages that were graded in difﬁculty. After completing each passage the child was presented with a series of questions relating to the passage. The reading comprehension score was based on the total number of correct responses to these questions.
Reading All interventions v contro

CEM InCAS consists of three modules: General Maths, Maths Attitude and Mental Maths. The primary outcome measure for this trial is General Maths. This measure includes counting, place values, fractions, patterns, problem-solving, measures, shapes and space and data handling.
Posttest adjusted mean score on the New Group Reading Test (NGRT). This tests phonics, sentence completion, and passage comprehension then combines into a composite reading score.

out_tit_tool: APT, CELF, YARC language skills (30 wk)
out_desc_tool: In APT, the child is asked to describe the actions shown in a set of pictures. Two scores are recorded, one for the level of information they provide (for example nouns and verbs) and one for the grammar they use (such as use of tenses).  In CELF, children are asked to name pictures.  In YARC, children listen to recordings of four short stories and answer questions about them.

The primary outcome measure for this evaluation is the New Group Reading Test (NGRT) score. This test is used for all EEF projects funded through the EEF  Literacy Catch Up’ round of projects. NGRT seeks to measure reading and comprehension for various age groups. The NGRT test appropriate for this age group (Years 7–8) comprises 20 sentence-completion items and various comprehension questions based on the reading of three passages.
The test used was the paper version of the New Group Reading Test (NGRT, GL Assessment),4 as it is a reliable test that has been standardised for the age group participating in this evaluation.
The Burt Graded Word Reading Test (1976) was used as a second measure of word recognition skills.
WRAT Reading Comprehension Reading Practise Group

out_tit_tool: K reading accuracy - teaching assistants - post-test (means and sd's)
out_desc_tool: Post-test composite average score for Woodcock Reading Mastery Test—Revised/Normative Update Word Attack and Word Identification subtest standard scores. The Word Attack subtest includes 50 nonwords that increase in difficulty. Testing is discontinued after six consecutive incorrect responses.

Results from Table 2 of 'Reading Accuracy' row with adjusted posttest means. Composite (simple average) of Word Attack and Word Identification subtest standard scores from the Woodcock Reading Mastery Test–Revised/Normative Update (Woodcock, 1998). The Word Attack subtest requires the student to read a list of pseudowords that increase in difficulty. The Word Identification subtest requires the student to read increasingly difficult real words. For each subtest, testing was discontinued after 6 consecutive items were missed.

Note: Adjusts for clustering but not baseline. Comprehension was assessed at pretest and posttest with the GORT Comprehension subtest. Students read passages aloud, be­ ginning at their grade level, and were asked comprehension ques­ tions for each passage. Performance on the grade-level passage determined subsequent passage reading, and testing was discon­ tinued when a basal and ceiling were established. Standard scores were transformed to have M = 100 and SD = 15.

Comprehension was assessed at posttest only using the WRMT-R/NU Passage Comprehension subtest. The student is asked to silently read a short passage, and orally provide the missing key word. (For each blank, the student is asked to supply a word appropriate in the context of the passage.)
Wood Cock Passage Comprehension Posttest

Post-test mean standard score of WRMT-R/NU Passage Comprehension subtest. It requires students to supply a missing word that would be appropriate in the context of each passage silently read. A series of acceptable responses are listed on the easel page for the tester. Items are increasingly difficult, and testing is discontinued after six consecutive incorrect responses.
Posttest means and SD's for non-LM intervention vs non-LM control. WRMT-R/NU Passage Comprehension standard

Posttest adjusted mean score for the Word Attack and Word Identification subtests from the Woodcock Reading Mastery Test–Revised/Normative Update (Woodcock, 1987/ 1998). The Word Attack subtest includes 50 nonwords that increase in difficulty (e.g., ree, ip, ig). Testing is discontinued after six consecutive incorrect responses.
Post test mean scores for reading comprehension-Teaching assistants group. Dynamic Indicators of Basic Early Literacy Skills (DIBELS).

out_tit_tool: Reading Scores from CRT (Criterion Referenced Tests)
out_desc_tool: CRT scores of the 1990/91 (pretest) and 1991/92 (posttest) academic school years from each school were obtained and collated. Reading and math scores were transformed according to the arcsine of the square root of each percentage score. Data from Table 1.
